The 'Nocardiaceae' are a family of aerobic, non-fastidious, high G+C, Gram-
positive actinomycetes that are commonly found in soil and
water. Stackebrandt, E., Rainey, F.A. and N.L. Ward-Rainey. 1997.
[http://ijs.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/47/2/479 Proposal for a new
hierarchic classification system, Actinobacteria classis nov]. Int. J. Syst.
Bacteriol., 1997, '47':479-491. Members of this family have been isolated
from Antarctic soils. Aislabie, J. [http://books.google.com/books?id=VKtCnL-
a5uaYC&pg=PA257&lpg=PA257&dq=nocardiaceae+heterotroph&source=web&ots=IoDal0JA1C-
&sig=jsYOFv9zWhYKtkn7PpIK7mDIZs8 Ecosystems Processes in Antarctic Ice-Free
Landscapes]. "Hydrocarbon-degrading bacteria in oil-contaminated soils near
Scott Base, Antarctica." Page 257. Nocardiaceae present coccobacilli,
filamentous or, rarely, fragmented and palisading forms, Kulich, S.M. and
W.A. Pasculle. [http://path.upmc.edu/cases/case146/dx.html Final Diagnosis -
Pneumonia, Hilar Lymphadenitis and Sepsis Secondary to Rhodococcus equi]. The
University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. Retrieved October 20, 2007.
and filamentous species grow in a branching morphological pattern similar to
